Distributing voltage in the robot correctly and pid control according to the voltage

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-06-24T17:52:30.704Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":194,"readers_count":193,"score":48.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":467928,"topic_slug":"voltage-compensation-in-ftc","display_username":"ftc","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":63541,"username":"Jwal","name":"Joseph Walters","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63769,"hidden":false,"trust_level":0,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/voltage-compensation-in-ftc/467928/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3401621,"name":"Joseph Walters","username":"Jwal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-24T19:18:18.492Z","cooked":"

I wont pretend to be up-to-date on WPI Lib’s built in features, as well as how PID might be implemented in FTC.

There are resources out there however like:

I do not believe you need to perform voltage compensation to implement a PID controller in FTC, nor do I believe that is what the motor controllers are doing at a hardware level when you are commanding the motors to a particular direction, power, or position.

Electrically: There is only so much to do when wiring an FTC robot to “distribute the voltage”, and there is only so much control you have over what the voltage delivered to a load is - largely determined by your battery voltage (which sags over the course of a match).

Digging deeper - what problem are you having or trying to solve? What is the behavior you are attempting to achieve and where are you now? Need a bit more information to effectively assist you besides posting links to resources you could google on your own.

Jwal:

I do not believe you need to perform voltage compensation to implement a PID controller in FTC, nor do I believe that is what the motor controllers are doing at a hardware level when you are commanding the motors to a particular direction, power, or position.

This is extremely incorrect. Float voltage on FTC batteries last much longer than it does in FRC and strongly affects autonomous modes, especially since the most common pathfollowers are feedforward-based which do not fare well without voltage compensation because the system dynamics are changing without it.

An example of voltage compensation can be found in the Roadrunner Quickstart in which it uses the voltage sensor on the control hub and then divides all outputs by the voltage.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-06-24T19:55:13.095Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":134,"readers_count":133,"score":106.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":467928,"topic_slug":"voltage-compensation-in-ftc","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/acmerobotics/road-runner-quickstart/blob/master/TeamCode/src/main/java/org/firstinspires/ftc/teamcode/MecanumDrive.java","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"road-runner-quickstart/TeamCode/src/main/java/org/firstinspires/ftc/teamcode/MecanumDrive.java at master · acmerobotics/road-runner-quickstart · GitHub","clicks":46}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/voltage-compensation-in-ftc/467928/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3401650,"name":"Joseph Walters","username":"Jwal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-24T20:34:22.266Z","cooked":"

Alex - you and I agree. Battery voltage can vary greatly across the timespan of a match (both in FRC and FTC). Battery voltage will be higher at the start of the match vs. at the end of the match.

I think where we are becoming disconnected is over the term “voltage compensation”.

It boils down to…what is the OP trying to do? If they are trying to scale motor outputs with a PID controller - adjusting the outputs based in input voltage is not strictly necessary (and feedforward although complimentary to PID is a different predictive control method whereas PID is backwards looking based on feedback).

If the OP is trying to “compensate” for voltage drop between the REV Control hub and motor itself…that is something different.

Getting down to a DC motor theory of operation - is the OP trying to “boost” the control hub output voltage to get output speed of an actuator or motor the same as at the beginning of the match? That is something different yet.

It all comes back to - needing more information on what the OP is trying to do.
What problem are you having or trying to solve? What is the behavior you are attempting to achieve and where are you now?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-06-24T20:34:22.266Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":34.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":467928,"topic_slug":"voltage-compensation-in-ftc","display_username":"Joseph Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50219,"username":"Alex_Y","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/voltage-compensation-in-ftc/467928/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3401695,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-24T23:55:41.073Z","cooked":"

While yes you don’t need to do anything, PID control strongly benefits from voltage compensation to maintain consistent settling time regardless of battery voltage as a PID acting on duty cycle tuned at one voltage will not behave the same as one running at a different voltage. and is something that should always be done .

Agam:

I would like to get an example or explanation

Because nobody else wants to answer, voltage compensation in FTC/FRC is where you scale the duty cycle output on a motor such that your feedback/feedforward controllers are acting in terms of voltage rather than in terms of duty cycle. If for example your controllers are outputting 12V, but your battery is at 13V, you would want to run your motors at 92.3% duty cycle at that given instant in time for the motors to receive an effective voltage of 12V. Due to system dynamics behind PID control, you want your controllers acting in voltage (or curret but this is beyond the point) rather than duty cycle such that the battery voltage doesn’t influence the PIDs behavior.

Yes, pid is affected by the voltage level in the robot and behaves differently.
That’s why I want the pid control to be constant, constant voltage .
